metadata.titleEn: Temporal dynamic reflectance spectra dataset of typical vegetation in China
metadata.description: The time-continuous reflectance spectra measurements were implemented within the growing duration in typical agriculture test sites of China, including Changchun, Zhangye, and Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture. The measurements in Changchun were carried out in 2016. Several typical vegetation types such as maize, rice, wheat, potato, soybean, and mungbean were included. The number of sampling days ranged from 10 to 16, distributed across the whole growing season. The vegetation temporal dynamic reflectance spectra in Zhangye were collected in 2013. The measured vegetation types included rape, barely, corn, and onion, and the number of sampling days ranged between 9 and 12. For each vegetation type, there were as least two reflectance spectra measurements for each month during the experimental period. In this way, the measured reflectance spectra of these vegetation nearly represent the temporal dynamics in the growing season. The measurements in Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture were also conducted in 2013. Only the reflectance spectra of grassland were collected from May to September. And there were 13 sampling days. The spectral distribution of each specific target is estimated as the average of all reflectance distributions. In order to collect smooth and continuous spectral curves, the least squares polynomial fitting algorithm is applied to remove the abnormal fluctuations in the vapor absorption channel, and the spectral curves are interpolated to 1 nm spectral resolution using piecewise linear interpolation functions. This dataset can support the development of the modeling of plant growth and vegetation phenology, and the retrieval of surface biophysical and biochemical parameters. Moreover, they can serve as a reference truth for satellite observations in validation.
metadata.instructions: For each vegetation type, all data were organized in a folder named "AAAA_BBBB_CCCC_YYYYMMDD HHMMSS". "AAAA" is set to "spec", "BBBB_CCCC" refers to the name of land cover type and object, and "YYYYMMDD HHMMSS" displays the time of measurement. The observation data file is processed in TXT format, the metadata file is processed in XML format, and the satellite data and quick view were set in Tiff and JPEG formats respectively. As for the name of each spectral data, the file name is recorded as “AAAA_BBBB_CCCC_YYYYMMDDHHMMSS_XXXX”, where the “XXXX” shows the file type, “A000” means the data file, and “B000” means the auxiliary file of XML. The “AAAA” represents the spectral types, where “refl”, “emis”, and “mwra” denote the reflectance, emissivity, and microwave emissivity, respectively. And the “pixel”, “img”, and “view” represent the satellite pixel spectral, the satellite image, and the quick-view image, respectively. Regarding the name of the metadata, “AAAA” was set as “comp” and “pixel”. “comp” refers to the scene information of the spectra, and “pixel” indicates the information of satellite pixel spectral.

background: Field-measured spectra are critical for remote sensing physical modelling, retrieval of structural, biophysical, and biochemical parameters, and other practical applications. To the best of our knowledge, this library is unique in simultaneously providing full-band, multi-angle, multi-scale spectral measurements of the main surface elements of China covering a large spatial extent over a 10-year period.
research objective: In this paper, we present the full-wave band, multi-angle, multi-scale, and temporal dynamic spectral library dubbed Ground Object Spectral Library (GOSPEL).
challenges: However, there are several limitations to the exiting libraries. First, they provide spectra in shortwave, infrared, or microwave domains separately. This discontinuity does not meet the requirements for developing a unified spectral-domain radiative transfer model and its associated applications. Second, they rarely measure (and release) anisotropic spectra across different spectral domains. Nevertheless, apparent anisotropy exists in the surface reflectivity in the VNIR-SWIR spectral domain (e.g., bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF)), emissivity in the TIR spectral domain (e.g., directional bright temperature), and reflectivity or emissivity in the microwave spectral domains (e.g., directional microwave radiation). Ignoring the directionality of satellite observations may lead to large errors in the retrieval of remote sensing radiation and vegetation structure variables. Therefore, the multi-angular spectra are a pressing need to advance the estimation of surface energy budget and modeling of land surface processes. Third, there is a lack of multiscale spectra measurements (e.g., leaf and canopy spectra), which hinders the understanding of cross-scale physical radiative transfer and associated ecological processes. Hence, the collection of multiscale spectra is much needed to help improve the understanding of cross-scale radiative transfer processes from individual leaves to canopies and even ecosystems and promote the exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes (e.g., upscaling plant function traits). Furthermore, the temporal dynamic spectra for typical vegetation are insufficient. Given the fact that the vegetation dynamics are crucial for modeling land cover change and plant phenology as well as its feedback to climate change, vegetation spectra across different growth stages need to be further supplemented in order to improve the monitoring and modeling of land cover and land use change, and surface phenology in general.
methods: We present a library of field spectra, which includes (1) portable field spectroradiometer measurements of vegetation, soil, and snow in the full-wave band, (2) multi-angle spectra measurements of desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow with consideration of the anisotropic reflectance of land surface, (3) multi-scale spectra measurements of leaf and canopy of different vegetation cover surfaces, and (4) continuous reflectance spectra time-series data revealing vegetation growth dynamics of maize, rice, wheat, rape, grassland, and so on. Furthermore, the 101 by 101 satellite pixels of Landsat ETM/OLI and MODIS surface reflectance centered around the field site were extracted, providing a vital linkage between ground measurements and satellite observations.
dataset: We present a library of field spectra, which includes (1) portable field spectroradiometer measurements of vegetation, soil, and snow in the full-wave band, (2) multi-angle spectra measurements of desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow with consideration of the anisotropic reflectance of land surface, (3) multi-scale spectra measurements of leaf and canopy of different vegetation cover surfaces, and (4) continuous reflectance spectra time-series data revealing vegetation growth dynamics of maize, rice, wheat, rape, grassland, and so on.
findings: We believe that this spectral library will undoubtedly advance the development of the modeling of plant growth and vegetation phenology, support further research on cross-scale ecological processes and underlying mechanisms, the quantification of the geometric effects of solar and sensor on the physical radiative transfer processes, and the retrieval of surface biophysical and biochemical parameters. Moreover, it can serve as the ground-truth information for validation of satellite spectral measurements.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how multi-angle spectra measurements are used in data collection for understanding surface reflectivity?
Example.Answer: Multi-angle spectra measurements are used to account for the anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces. For instance, they include measurements of desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow, which consider the directionality of reflectance across different spectral domains, improving the accuracy of surface energy budget estimations and land surface process modeling.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how multiscale spectra measurements contribute to understanding ecological processes?
Example.Answer: Multiscale spectra measurements, such as those of leaf and canopy spectra of various vegetation cover surfaces, help in understanding cross-scale physical radiative transfer processes. This approach enhances the exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes, from individual leaves to entire ecosystems, and supports the advancement of ecological process modeling.

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics should a dataset of vegetation reflectance spectra possess to effectively model plant growth and phenology?
Feature Specification.Answer: full-wave band measurements, multi-angle spectra, multi-scale spectra from leaf to canopy levels, continuous time-series data, anisotropic reflectance, wide range of vegetation types and growth stages

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential features of a data collection method that aims to capture the anisotropic reflectance properties of vegetation?
Feature Specification.Answer: multi-angle spectra measurements, bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF), VNIR-SWIR, TIR, microwave, interaction of solar and sensor geometry with surface elements

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'multi-angle spectra measurements' in the context of field data collection for vegetation?
Definition.Answer: Multi-angle spectra measurements refer to the collection of spectral data at different angles to account for the anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces, such as desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow. This approach considers the directionality of the surface reflectivity, which is important for reducing errors in remote sensing data retrieval and understanding surface energy budgets and land surface processes.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'temporal dynamic spectra' signify in vegetation data collection?
Definition.Answer: Temporal dynamic spectra refer to the continuous collection of reflectance spectra over time to capture the growth dynamics of vegetation such as maize, rice, wheat, rape, and grassland. This data is essential for modeling land cover change, plant phenology, and understanding their feedback to climate change by providing insights into vegetation dynamics across different growth stages.

Definition.Question: In the context of spectral data collection, what is the significance of 'multi-scale spectra measurements'?
Definition.Answer: Multi-scale spectra measurements involve capturing spectral data at various scales, such as leaf and canopy levels, for different vegetation cover surfaces. This approach helps in understanding cross-scale radiative transfer processes and ecological processes, facilitating the exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes and improving the modeling of physical radiative transfer from individual leaves to entire ecosystems.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for vegetation spectral measurements at different agricultural test sites in China compare in terms of frequency and duration of sampling?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods across different sites in China show variations in both frequency and duration of sampling. For instance, at the Changchun site, spectral measurements for various vegetation types were taken with sampling days ranging from 10 to 16 days distributed throughout the growing season. Similarly, at the Zhangye site, measurements were conducted over 9 to 12 days with each vegetation type measured at least twice a month. In contrast, the Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture site observed grassland spectral data over a total of 13 days from May to September. These differences in data collection methods reflect diverse strategies tailored to specific regional or vegetation characteristics and objectives of the study.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced by traditional spectral libraries differ from those addressed by the presented multiscale spectral library in capturing vegetation dynamics?
Comparison.Answer: Traditional spectral libraries often face challenges such as providing spectra in separate spectral domains, which does not support unified modeling across these domains, and they may lack anisotropic spectra measurements or multiscale spectra, hindering accurate capture of cross-scale radiative processes. The multiscale spectral library presented addresses these limitations by providing full-wave band, multi-angle, multi-scale, and temporal dynamic spectra, including continuous time-series data that reveal vegetation growth dynamics. This comprehensive approach aims to improve the understanding of radiative transfer processes, cross-scale ecological processes, and vegetation dynamics more effectively than traditional libraries.

Interpretation.Question: How can the application of least squares polynomial fitting and piecewise linear interpolation contribute to the accuracy of time-series vegetation spectral data?
Interpretation.Answer: The application of least squares polynomial fitting helps in removing abnormal fluctuations caused by atmospheric water vapor absorption bands, while piecewise linear interpolation ensures that the spectral curves are interpolated to a 1nm spectral resolution. These techniques contribute to creating smooth and continuous spectral curves, which are crucial for accurate modeling of plant growth and vegetation phenology.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can multi-scale spectral measurements enhance our understanding of cross-scale radiative transfer processes and ecological dynamics?
Interpretation.Answer: Multi-scale spectral measurements, which include spectra from leaf to canopy levels, enable researchers to study cross-scale physical radiative transfer processes and their associated ecological dynamics. This understanding is pivotal for scaling ecological processes from individual leaves to entire ecosystems and for examining the effects of scaling on ecological phenomena, such as plant functional traits.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for multi-angle spectra measurements in vegetation and soil studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ignoring the directionality of satellite observations may lead to large errors in the retrieval of remote sensing radiation and vegetation structure variables. Therefore, multi-angle spectra measurements are necessary to accurately estimate the surface energy budget and model land surface processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a pressing need for multiscale spectra measurements in ecological studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lack of multiscale spectra measurements hinders the understanding of cross-scale physical radiative transfer and associated ecological processes. Collecting multiscale spectra can improve understanding from individual leaves to canopies and ecosystems, promoting exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes and supporting research on plant function traits.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the insufficiency of temporal dynamic spectra for typical vegetation, and what implications does this have?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Temporal dynamic spectra are insufficient despite their importance for modeling land cover change, plant phenology, and climate change feedback. Vegetation spectra across different growth stages need to be supplemented to improve monitoring and modeling of land cover and land use change, and surface phenology.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of employing multi-scale spectra measurements on understanding cross-scale ecological processes in typical vegetation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing multi-scale spectra measurements can enhance the understanding of cross-scale physical radiative transfer processes from individual leaves to canopies and ecosystems. This approach can promote the exploration of scaling effects on ecological processes, such as upscaling plant function traits.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the lack of temporal dynamic spectra for typical vegetation impact the ability to model land cover change and plant phenology?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The lack of temporal dynamic spectra for typical vegetation limits the ability to model land cover change and plant phenology accurately. Vegetation dynamics are crucial for these models, and without sufficient spectra across different growth stages, it's challenging to improve the monitoring and modeling of land cover and land use change, and surface phenology.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of applying a least squares polynomial fitting algorithm to remove atmospheric water vapor absorption band anomalies in spectral data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying a least squares polynomial fitting algorithm to remove atmospheric water vapor absorption band anomalies helps in collecting smooth, continuous spectral curves. This technique is crucial for accurate modeling of plant growth and vegetation phenology, as well as for the inversion of physiological and chemical parameters. It also serves as a relative 'truth' for validation purposes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind collecting full-wave band, multi-angle, and multi-scale spectral measurements of vegetation in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to provide comprehensive spectral data that can support remote sensing physical modeling, facilitate the retrieval of structural, biophysical, and biochemical parameters, and enhance practical applications such as modeling plant growth and vegetation phenology.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to include continuous reflectance spectra time-series data in the spectral library?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Continuous reflectance spectra time-series data are crucial for revealing vegetation growth dynamics and improving the monitoring and modeling of land cover and land use change, as well as surface phenology, which are vital for understanding environmental changes and their impact on climate.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multi-angle spectral measurements conducted to account for the anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces in vegetation studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multi-angle spectral measurements are conducted by measuring the spectra of desert vegetation, chernozems, and snow, while considering the anisotropic reflectance of the land surface. This is crucial for addressing the directionality of satellite observations and reducing errors in retrieving remote sensing variables.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What preprocessing techniques are applied to spectral data to produce smooth and continuous spectral curves suitable for vegetation growth modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Preprocessing techniques include using a least squares polynomial fitting algorithm to remove anomalous fluctuations due to atmospheric water vapor absorption and applying a piecewise linear interpolation function to interpolate spectral curves to a 1nm spectral resolution. This ensures smooth and continuous spectral data suitable for modeling vegetation growth and phenology.

Enablement.Question: How does the application of least squares polynomial fitting algorithms enable the removal of atmospheric absorption anomalies in spectral data collection?
Enablement.Answer: The least squares polynomial fitting algorithm is applied to remove anomalous fluctuations in the atmospheric water vapor absorption bands, which facilitates the collection of smooth and continuous spectral curves, enhancing the quality and accuracy of the spectral data.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies facilitate the collection of multi-angle and multi-scale spectral measurements for vegetation and soil analysis?
Enablement.Answer: The use of portable field spectroradiometers enables the collection of full-wave band spectra, while multi-angle and multi-scale measurements are achieved by considering the anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces, which includes capturing the spectral data of desert vegetation, chernozems, snow, and different vegetation covers at both leaf and canopy levels.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the integration of satellite data with ground measurements enhance the understanding and modeling of vegetation growth dynamics?
Enablement.Answer: Satellite pixels from Landsat ETM/OLI and MODIS surface reflectance centered around field sites are extracted to provide a crucial linkage between ground measurements and satellite observations, enabling a comprehensive understanding and modeling of vegetation growth dynamics across different scales and enhancing the validation of spectral measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset on vegetation spectral data lack temporal dynamic spectra for certain vegetation types, and what strategies could be implemented to address this?
Expectation.Answer: The temporal dynamic spectra for typical vegetation might be insufficient due to the lack of comprehensive data collection across different growth stages. Strategies to address this include supplementing vegetation spectra to improve monitoring and modeling of land cover changes and plant phenology.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in collecting multi-angle spectral measurements across vast spatial extents, and how might researchers overcome them?
Expectation.Answer: Collecting multi-angle spectral measurements is challenging due to the need to account for anisotropic reflectance and the directionality of satellite observations. Overcoming these challenges involves ensuring multi-angular spectra are measured to reduce errors in retrieval and to advance surface energy budget estimation.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing spectral libraries provide discontinuous spectra across different domains, and what methodological changes could reduce this issue?
Expectation.Answer: Existing spectral libraries might provide discontinuous spectra because they separately offer spectra in shortwave, infrared, or microwave domains. Methodological changes could involve the development of a unified spectral-domain radiative transfer model that integrates these domains for more comprehensive data.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using portable field spectroradiometers for collecting vegetation spectral data across different growth stages?
Judgmental.Answer: Portable field spectroradiometers are effective for collecting comprehensive spectral data because they allow for full-wave band measurements and capture the temporal dynamics of vegetation, which are crucial for modeling land cover change and plant phenology. This method ensures high-resolution data collection tailored to different growth stages, enhancing the monitoring and modeling of surface phenology.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how field spectra measurements can be conducted across multiple scales and what challenges might arise in this process.
Assertion.Answer: Field spectra measurements across multiple scales involve capturing data at both the leaf and canopy levels. Challenges include ensuring accurate representation of cross-scale physical radiative transfer processes and ecological interactions. This requires careful calibration and consideration of various environmental factors to maintain consistency and reliability.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the significance of measuring multi-angle spectra and how it addresses limitations in existing spectral libraries.
Assertion.Answer: Measuring multi-angle spectra is significant because it accounts for the anisotropic reflectance of land surfaces, which is often ignored in existing spectral libraries. This helps reduce errors in retrieving remote sensing radiation and vegetation structure variables, thus advancing the estimation of surface energy budgets and land surface processes modeling.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how continuous reflectance spectra time-series data can contribute to modeling plant growth and vegetation phenology.
Assertion.Answer: Continuous reflectance spectra time-series data provide detailed insights into vegetation growth dynamics across different growth stages. This continuous data allows for improved monitoring and modeling of land cover change, plant phenology, and ecosystem feedback to climate change, enhancing the understanding and prediction of these processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the techniques used for collecting and refining long-term spectral data of vegetation across different geographical locations in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection involved continuous field measurements of vegetation reflectance spectra using portable field spectroradiometers at specific agricultural sites in China (Changchun, Zhangye, and Haibei Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture). The data was collected for different vegetation types over varying periods during their growth seasons. To refine the data, least squares polynomial fitting was applied to remove atmospheric water vapor absorption band anomalies, and piecewise linear interpolation was used to interpolate the spectral curves to a 1nm spectral resolution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and elaborate on the key challenges faced in developing a comprehensive spectral library for vegetation and other surface elements in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: The development of a comprehensive spectral library faces several challenges, including the need for continuous spectral data across different growth stages of vegetation, the requirement for multi-angular and multi-scale spectra measurements to address anisotropic reflectance and scaling effects, and the lack of unified spectra across shortwave, infrared, and microwave domains. These challenges hinder the understanding of cross-scale radiative transfer processes and accurate land cover change and phenology modeling.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the potential applications and benefits of a spectral dataset that includes multi-angle, multi-scale, and temporal dynamic measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: A spectral dataset with these characteristics is beneficial for advancing plant growth modeling and vegetation phenology studies. It supports research on cross-scale ecological processes, the retrieval of biophysical and biochemical parameters, and provides ground-truth information for validating satellite spectral measurements. Such a dataset can improve the understanding of surface energy budgets and land surface processes, and promote scaling effects exploration on ecological processes.
